dt: {bc}to injure with deep {d_link|disfiguring|disfigure} wounds by cutting, tearing, or crushing
{bc}to spoil, injure, or make {d_link|incoherent|incoherent} especially through {d_link|ineptitude|ineptitude}

pt: {sc}maim{/sc} {sc}cripple{/sc} {sc}mutilate{/sc} {sc}batter{/sc} {sc}mangle{/sc} mean to injure so severely as to cause lasting damage. {sc}maim{/sc} implies the loss or injury of a bodily member through violence.
{sc}cripple{/sc} implies the loss or serious impairment of an arm or leg.
{sc}mutilate{/sc} implies the cutting off or removal of an essential part of a person or thing thereby impairing its completeness, beauty, or function.
{sc}batter{/sc} implies a series of blows that bruise deeply, deform, or mutilate.

pt.t: an old ship {it}battered{/it} by fierce storms

pt: {sc}mangle{/sc} implies a tearing or crushing that leaves deep wounds.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}mangler, mahangler{/it}, perhaps from {it}mahaigner{/it} to maim {ma}{mat|mayhem|}{/ma}
shortdef: to injure with deep disfiguring wounds by cutting, tearing, or crushing
to spoil, injure, or make incoherent especially through ineptitude

dt: {bc}a machine for ironing laundry by passing it between heated rollers

et: Dutch {it}mangel{/it}, from German, from Middle High German, diminutive of {it}mange{/it} mangonel, mangle, from Latin {it}manganum{/it}
shortdef: a machine for ironing laundry by passing it between heated rollers

dt: {bc}to press or smooth (something, such as damp linen) with a mangle

shortdef: to press or smooth (something, such as damp linen) with a mangle
